Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Because the six villages form the six vertices of a regular hexagon, every straight path between two villages is a chord of that hexagon.  
Label the bride’s village (the father‑in‑law’s village) 0 and number the remaining villages 1,2,3,4,5 going clockwise.

For any village k let d(k) be its (Euclidean) distance to the bride’s village 0.  
Because the villages lie on a circle, d(k) depends only on the smaller of k and 6–k:

k‑step    angle       distance                 value (in units of the radius R)  
 1             60°                 d1 = 2R·sin 30° = R  
 2            120°                d2 = 2R·sin 60° = R√3  
 3            180°                d3 = 2R

A “legal” route is a sequence of distinct villages that starts at the suitor’s home S, ends at village 0, and at every step goes to a village that is strictly closer to 0 (its d–value strictly decreases).

Counting the legal routes.

1. If S is the immediate neighbour of the bride (k = 1) the only possible route is the direct chord S→0.  
   Number of routes = 1.

2. If S is two steps away (k = 2) three routes are possible:  
    S→0                                 (d2→d0)  
    S→(either neighbour of 0)→0    (d2→d1→d0)  
   Number of routes = 3.

3. If S is diametrically opposite the bride (k = 3) the possibilities are

    3‑step drop              :  S→0                            (d3→d0)                1 route  
    2‑step, then drop        :  S→(k = 2)→0          (d3→d2→d0)        2 routes  
    1‑step, then drop        :  S→(k = 1)→0          (d3→d1→d0)        2 routes  
    2‑step, 1‑step, drop :  S→(k = 2)→(k = 1)→0    (d3→d2→d1→d0) 4 routes  
   Number of routes = 1+2+2+4 = 9.

Thus a man whose home village is 1 step, 2 steps, or 3 steps from his fiancée’s village must bring a fish on 1, 3, or 9 successive days.

In the story the three brides live in the first three villages encountered clockwise.  
The three brothers live in the remaining three villages, so (whatever the exact pairing) one groom is 1 step, one is 2 steps, and one is 3 steps away.  
Therefore

 • The brother only one village away finishes on 1 April and marries the next day → 2 April.  
 • The brother two villages away finishes on 3 April and marries the next day → 4 April.  
 • The brother opposite his bride finishes on 9 April and marries the next day → 10 April.

Wedding dates: 2 April, 4 April, and 10 April.

Bonus (The longest single route)

Let the coastline be 10 miles.  The radius of the island is

     R = C/(2π) = 10/(2π) = 5/π miles.

The longest legal route is one of the 3‑edge paths used by the groom diametrically opposite his fiancée:

 (opposite) → (k = 2) → (the other k = 1) → bride  
whose three edges have lengths R + 2R + R = 4R.

Hence

     L_max = 4R = 4·(5/π) = 20/π ≈ 6.37 miles.

Final answer: The weddings take place on 2 April, 4 April and 10 April; the longest possible route is 20/π ≈ 6.37 miles.

Response:
Here is the step-by-step reasoning to solve the problem.

**1. Understanding the Setup**

*   There are 6 villages (V0, V1, V2, V3, V4, V5) evenly distributed on a circle. Let's assume V0 is the starting village (the father's village). The villages are ordered clockwise.
*   The distance between any two villages V_i and V_j is the straight-line distance (Euclidean distance) between them.
*   The circumference of the island is 10 miles. The villages form a regular hexagon inscribed in the circle. If the radius of the island is R, the circumference is 2πR. So, 2πR = 10 miles, which means R = 10/(2π) miles.
*   The distance between two villages V_i and V_j depends only on the difference in their indices, modulo 6. Let k = min(|i-j|, 6-|i-j|) be the "steps" along the coast between V_i and V_j. The angle between V_i and V_j from the center of the island is k * 60 degrees. The straight-line distance (chord length) is 2R * sin(k * 60 / 2) = 2R * sin(k * 30 degrees).
    *   k=1 (neighboring villages, e.g., V0-V1): Distance = 2R * sin(30°) = 2R * (1/2) = R.
    *   k=2 (villages two steps apart, e.g., V0-V2): Distance = 2R * sin(60°) = 2R * (√3/2) = R√3.
    *   k=3 (opposite villages, e.g., V0-V3): Distance = 2R * sin(90°) = 2R * 1 = 2R.

**2. Defining the "Getting Closer" Constraint**

*   A suitor travels along routes (sequences of straight paths between villages).
*   The constraint is that he must always be getting closer to his destination. We interpret this to mean that if the suitor is currently at village V_curr and moves to village V_next, the straight-line distance from V_next to the destination village V_dest must be strictly less than the straight-line distance from V_curr to V_dest: d(V_next, V_dest) < d(V_curr, V_dest).
*   A route is a sequence of villages V_0, V_1, ..., V_m such that V_0 is the start village, V_m is the destination village, and for every step i from 0 to m-1, d(V_{i+1}, V_dest) < d(V_i, V_dest). The path ends when the suitor reaches the destination village (distance 0).

**3. Identifying the Sons' Journeys**

*   All sons start from the father's village, which we call V0.
*   The brides' villages are the first three encountered when traveling clockwise from V0. These are V1, V2, and V3.
    *   Son 1 travels from V0 to V1.
    *   Son 2 travels from V0 to V2.
    *   Son 3 travels from V0 to V3.

**4. Counting Paths for Each Son**

We need to find the number of distinct valid routes (sequences of villages) for each son. Let N(U, D) be the number of valid routes from village U to village D.

*   **Son 1: V0 to V1 (Destination V1)**
    *   Initial distance: d(V0, V1) = R.
    *   From V0, any next village V must satisfy d(V, V1) < d(V0, V1) = R.
    *   Let's check the distances from villages V_i to V1:
        *   d(V1, V1) = 0 < R. (Valid next step: V0 -> V1)
        *   d(V2, V1) = R. Not < R. (V0 -> V2 invalid)
        *   d(V3, V1) = R√3. Not < R. (V0 -> V3 invalid)
        *   d(V4, V1) = d(V1, V4) = 2R. Not < R. (V0 -> V4 invalid)
        *   d(V5, V1) = R. Not < R. (V0 -> V5 invalid)
    *   The only valid first step from V0 towards V1 is V0 -> V1. Once at V1, the destination is reached.
    *   The only path is V0 -> V1.
    *   Number of paths for Son 1 = 1.

*   **Son 2: V0 to V2 (Destination V2)**
    *   Initial distance: d(V0, V2) = R√3.
    *   From V0, any next village V must satisfy d(V, V2) < d(V0, V2) = R√3.
    *   Distances from villages V_i to V2:
        *   d(V0, V2) = R√3 (initial)
        *   d(V1, V2) = R < R√3. (Valid first step V0 -> V1)
        *   d(V2, V2) = 0 < R√3. (Valid first step V0 -> V2)
        *   d(V3, V2) = R < R√3. (Valid first step V0 -> V3)
        *   d(V4, V2) = R√3. Not < R√3. (V0 -> V4 invalid)
        *   d(V5, V2) = 2R. Not < R√3. (V0 -> V5 invalid)
    *   Valid first steps: V0 -> V1, V0 -> V2, V0 -> V3.
    *   Now, trace paths from these villages to V2:
        *   Path starting V0 -> V2: Reached destination. (1 path: V0 -> V2).
        *   Path starting V0 -> V1: Current V1, destination V2, d(V1, V2)=R. From V1, need V such that d(V, V2) < R.
            *   d(V0, V2) = R√3. Not < R.
            *   d(V2, V2) = 0 < R. (Valid step V1 -> V2)
            *   d(V3, V2) = R. Not < R.
            *   d(V4, V2) = R√3. Not < R.
            *   d(V5, V2) = 2R. Not < R.
            *   Only valid next step is V1 -> V2. (1 path: V0 -> V1 -> V2).
        *   Path starting V0 -> V3: Current V3, destination V2, d(V3, V2)=R. From V3, need V such that d(V, V2) < R.
            *   d(V0, V2) = R√3. Not < R.
            *   d(V1, V2) = R. Not < R.
            *   d(V2, V2) = 0 < R. (Valid step V3 -> V2)
            *   d(V4, V2) = R√3. Not < R.
            *   d(V5, V2) = 2R. Not < R.
            *   Only valid next step is V3 -> V2. (1 path: V0 -> V3 -> V2).
    *   Total paths for Son 2: 1 (V0->V2) + 1 (V0->V1->V2) + 1 (V0->V3->V2) = 3.

*   **Son 3: V0 to V3 (Destination V3)**
    *   Initial distance: d(V0, V3) = 2R.
    *   From V0, any next village V must satisfy d(V, V3) < d(V0, V3) = 2R.
    *   Distances from villages V_i to V3:
        *   d(V0, V3) = 2R (initial)
        *   d(V1, V3) = R√3 < 2R. (Valid first step V0 -> V1)
        *   d(V2, V3) = R < 2R. (Valid first step V0 -> V2)
        *   d(V3, V3) = 0 < 2R. (Valid first step V0 -> V3)
        *   d(V4, V3) = R < 2R. (Valid first step V0 -> V4)
        *   d(V5, V3) = R√3 < 2R. (Valid first step V0 -> V5)
    *   Valid first steps: V0 -> V1, V0 -> V2, V0 -> V3, V0 -> V4, V0 -> V5.
    *   Trace paths from these villages to V3:
        *   Path starting V0 -> V3: Reached destination. (1 path: V0 -> V3).
        *   Paths starting V0 -> V1: Current V1, destination V3, d(V1, V3)=R√3. From V1, need V such that d(V, V3) < R√3.
            *   d(V2, V3) = R < R√3. (Valid step V1 -> V2)
            *   d(V3, V3) = 0 < R√3. (Valid step V1 -> V3)
            *   d(V4, V3) = R < R√3. (Valid step V1 -> V4)
            *   d(V0, V3) = 2R. Not <.
            *   d(V5, V3) = R√3. Not <.
            *   Valid next steps from V1: V1 -> V2, V1 -> V3, V1 -> V4.
                *   V0 -> V1 -> V3: Reached destination. (1 path). Length R + R√3.
                *   V0 -> V1 -> V2: Current V2, dest V3, d(V2, V3)=R. From V2, need V such that d(V, V3) < R. Only V3(0) is closer. V2 -> V3. (1 path: V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> V3). Length R + R + R = 3R.
                *   V0 -> V1 -> V4: Current V4, dest V3, d(V4, V3)=R. From V4, need V such that d(V, V3) < R. Only V3(0) is closer. V4 -> V3. (1 path: V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3). Length R + d(V1,V4) + R = R + 2R + R = 4R. (Note: d(V1,V4)=2R).
            *   Paths starting V0 -> V1: V0->V1->V3, V0->V1->V2->V3, V0->V1->V4->V3 (3 paths).
        *   Paths starting V0 -> V2: Current V2, dest V3, d(V2, V3)=R. From V2, need V such that d(V, V3) < R. Only V3(0) is closer. V2 -> V3. (1 path: V0 -> V2 -> V3). Length R√3 + R.
        *   Paths starting V0 -> V4: Current V4, dest V3, d(V4, V3)=R. From V4, need V such that d(V, V3) < R. Only V3(0) is closer. V4 -> V3. (1 path: V0 -> V4 -> V3). Length R√3 + R. (Symmetric to V0->V2->V3)
        *   Paths starting V0 -> V5: Current V5, dest V3, d(V5, V3)=R√3. From V5, need V such that d(V, V3) < R√3. By symmetry with V0->V1, there are 3 such paths starting V0->V5: V0->V5->V3, V0->V5->V2->V3, V0->V5->V4->V3. Lengths R+R√3, R+R+R=3R, R+2R+R=4R. (Symmetric to V0->V1 paths).
    *   Total paths for Son 3:
        *   V0 -> V3 (1 path)
        *   Paths via V1: V0->V1->V3, V0->V1->V2->V3, V0->V1->V4->V3 (3 paths)
        *   Path via V2: V0->V2->V3 (1 path)
        *   Path via V4: V0->V4->V3 (1 path)
        *   Paths via V5: V0->V5->V3, V0->V5->V2->V3, V0->V5->V4->V3 (3 paths)
    *   Total = 1 + 3 + 1 + 1 + 3 = 9 paths.

**5. Calculating Wedding Dates**

*   Each son makes one trip per day. He must travel by every route. So, the number of trips equals the number of paths.
*   The trips start on April 1st.
*   The wedding is on the day *following* the last trip. If a son makes N trips, his trips are on day 1, day 2, ..., day N. The wedding is on day N+1.
*   Son 1: 1 path. Needs 1 trip (on April 1st). Wedding on Day 1+1 = Day 2. April 2nd.
*   Son 2: 3 paths. Needs 3 trips (on April 1st, 2nd, 3rd). Wedding on Day 3+1 = Day 4. April 4th.
*   Son 3: 9 paths. Needs 9 trips (on April 1st to 9th). Wedding on Day 9+1 = Day 10. April 10th.

**6. Bonus Question: Longest Route Length**

*   Coastline length = 10 miles. R = 10/(2π) miles.
*   Distances between villages in miles:

    *   k=2 (skip 1): R√3 = 10√3/(2π) miles.
    *   k=3 (opposite): 2R = 20/(2π) = 10/π miles.

*   Let's list the lengths of all paths found for each son:
    *   Son 1 (V0->V1):
        *   V0->V1: Length = d(V0, V1) = R = 10/(2π). Max length for Son 1 = R.
    *   Son 2 (V0->V2):
        *   V0->V2: Length = d(V0, V2) = R√3 = 10√3/(2π).

        *   V0->V1->V4->V3: Length = d(V0, V1) + d(V1, V4) + d(V4, V3) = R + 2R + R = 4R = 40/(2π) = 20/π.
        *   V0->V2->V3: Length = d(V0, V2) + d(V2, V3) = R√3 + R = R(√3+1) = 10(√3+1)/(2π).

        *   Lengths for Son 3 are {2R, R(1+√3), 3R, 4R}. Max length for Son 3 = 4R.

Final verification of the number of crossings: For 6 points on a circle, the number of interior intersections of chords is usually given by $\binom{6}{4}=15$ if no three diagonals are concurrent. However, in a regular hexagon, the three main diagonals (V0V3, V1V4, V2V5) intersect at the center. This reduces the number of distinct intersection points. The number of pairs of diagonals is $\binom{15}{2} = 105$. Each intersection involves 2 diagonals. The 3 main diagonals intersect at one point instead of $\binom{3}{2}=3$ points. This reduction accounts for 2 fewer intersection points among the main diagonals themselves. Other intersections must be checked. A known result for a regular N-gon is that the number of interior intersections is $\binom{N}{4}$ if N is odd, and $\binom{N}{4} - \binom{N/2}{2}$ if N is even, if only intersections of *diagonals* are counted (not edges meeting diagonals, or vertices). For N=6, this formula gives $\binom{6}{4} - \binom{3}{2} = 15 - 3 = 12$. The problem states 13 crossings, one of which is the center where paths from *every* village meet. This phrasing is slightly ambiguous. It could mean paths *between pairs* of villages meet at the center (the main diagonals). If the 12 intersections from the formula plus the single central intersection are the 13 described, the geometry is consistent. The geometric detail about the 13 crossings doesn't affect the path counting, which is based on the villages and the straight-line segments (chords) between them.

Here is the step-by-step reasoning to solve the problem.

**1. Island Geometry and Village Distances**

The island is a perfect circle with 6 villages evenly distributed along the coastline. Let the villages be labeled V0, V1, V2, V3, V4, V5 in clockwise order. The paths between villages are straight lines (chords of the circle). Let the father's village be V0. The brides' villages are the first three clockwise from V0, which are V1, V2, and V3.

The villages form a regular hexagon inscribed in the circle. Let R be the radius of the island. The distance between any two villages V_i and V_j is the length of the chord connecting them. This distance depends only on the difference in their indices modulo 6. Let k = min(|i-j|, 6-|i-j|) be the shortest number of steps along the coastline between V_i and V_j. The angle subtended by the chord V_iV_j at the center of the circle is k * (360°/6) = k * 60°. The length of the chord is $2R \sin(k \cdot 60° / 2) = 2R \sin(k \cdot 30°)$.

The possible non-zero distances between distinct villages are:
*   k=1 (e.g., V0 to V1): $d_1 = 2R \sin(30°) = 2R \cdot (1/2) = R$.
*   k=2 (e.g., V0 to V2): $d_2 = 2R \sin(60°) = 2R \cdot (\sqrt{3}/2) = R\sqrt{3}$.
*   k=3 (e.g., V0 to V3): $d_3 = 2R \sin(90°) = 2R \cdot 1 = 2R$.

Note that $d(V_i, V_j) = d_{min(|i-j|, 6-|i-j|)}$. For example, $d(V_0, V_1) = R$, $d(V_0, V_2) = R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_0, V_3) = 2R$, $d(V_0, V_4) = R\sqrt{3}$ (since 4 steps clockwise is 2 steps counter-clockwise), $d(V_0, V_5) = R$ (since 5 steps clockwise is 1 step counter-clockwise).

**2. The "Getting Closer" Constraint and Path Counting**

A suitor travels along a sequence of straight paths (village to village). The rule is he must always be getting closer to his destination. This means if he is at village $V_{curr}$ and moves to village $V_{next}$ on his way to $V_{dest}$, the straight-line distance $d(V_{next}, V_{dest})$ must be strictly less than $d(V_{curr}, V_{dest})$. A route is a sequence of villages $U_0, U_1, \dots, U_m$ where $U_0$ is the starting village, $U_m$ is the destination village, and for every step $i < m$, $d(U_{i+1}, V_{dest}) < d(U_i, V_{dest})$.

Let $N(U, D)$ be the number of valid routes from village U to village D. We can calculate this recursively. If $U=D$, there is 1 route (the destination is reached). If $U \neq D$, $N(U, D)$ is the sum of $N(V, D)$ for all villages V such that there is a straight path from U to V (which is true for any $V \neq U$) and $d(V, D) < d(U, D)$.

*   **Son 1: V0 to V1 (Destination V1)**
    Initial distance: $d(V_0, V_1) = R$.
    From V0, a valid first step must go to V such that $d(V, V_1) < d(V_0, V_1) = R$.
    Let's check distances from V to V1:
    $d(V_1, V_1) = 0 < R$. Valid step V0 $\to$ V1.
    $d(V_2, V_1) = R$. Not less than R.
    $d(V_3, V_1) = R\sqrt{3}$. Not less than R.
    $d(V_4, V_1) = 2R$. Not less than R.
    $d(V_5, V_1) = R$. Not less than R.
    The only village closer to V1 than V0 is V1 itself. So the only valid first step is V0 $\to$ V1. This path reaches the destination.
    Number of paths for Son 1 = 1 (V0 $\to$ V1).

*   **Son 2: V0 to V2 (Destination V2)**
    Initial distance: $d(V_0, V_2) = R\sqrt{3}$.
    From V0, a valid first step must go to V such that $d(V, V_2) < d(V_0, V_2) = R\sqrt{3}$.
    Distances from V to V2: $d(V_1, V_2)=R$, $d(V_2, V_2)=0$, $d(V_3, V_2)=R$, $d(V_4, V_2)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_5, V_2)=2R$.
    Valid next villages from V0: V1 ($d(V_1, V_2)=R < R\sqrt{3}$), V2 ($d(V_2, V_2)=0 < R\sqrt{3}$), V3 ($d(V_3, V_2)=R < R\sqrt{3}$).
    The number of paths $N(V_0, V_2) = N(V_1, V_2) + N(V_2, V_2) + N(V_3, V_2)$.
    $N(V_2, V_2) = 1$ (direct path V0 $\to$ V2).
    To find $N(V_1, V_2)$: Current V1, destination V2, $d(V_1, V_2)=R$. Valid next V from V1 s.t. $d(V, V_2) < R$: only V2 ($d(V_2, V_2)=0 < R$). So $N(V_1, V_2) = N(V_2, V_2) = 1$ (path V1 $\to$ V2).
    To find $N(V_3, V_2)$: Current V3, destination V2, $d(V_3, V_2)=R$. Valid next V from V3 s.t. $d(V, V_2) < R$: only V2 ($d(V_2, V_2)=0 < R$). So $N(V_3, V_2) = N(V_2, V_2) = 1$ (path V3 $\to$ V2).
    Number of paths for Son 2 = $1 + 1 + 1 = 3$.
    The paths are: V0->V2, V0->V1->V2, V0->V3->V2.

*   **Son 3: V0 to V3 (Destination V3)**
    Initial distance: $d(V_0, V_3) = 2R$.
    From V0, a valid first step must go to V such that $d(V, V_3) < d(V_0, V_3) = 2R$.
    Distances from V to V3: $d(V_1, V_3)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_2, V_3)=R$, $d(V_3, V_3)=0$, $d(V_4, V_3)=R$, $d(V_5, V_3)=R\sqrt{3}$.
    Valid next villages from V0: V1, V2, V3, V4, V5 (all have distance < 2R from V3).
    The number of paths $N(V_0, V_3) = N(V_1, V_3) + N(V_2, V_3) + N(V_3, V_3) + N(V_4, V_3) + N(V_5, V_3)$.
    $N(V_3, V_3) = 1$ (direct path V0 $\to$ V3).
    To find $N(V_2, V_3)$: Current V2, destination V3, $d(V_2, V_3)=R$. Valid next V from V2 s.t. $d(V, V_3) < R$: only V3 ($d(V_3, V_3)=0 < R$). $N(V_2, V_3) = N(V_3, V_3) = 1$.
    To find $N(V_4, V_3)$: Current V4, destination V3, $d(V_4, V_3)=R$. Valid next V from V4 s.t. $d(V, V_3) < R$: only V3 ($d(V_3, V_3)=0 < R$). $N(V_4, V_3) = N(V_3, V_3) = 1$.
    To find $N(V_1, V_3)$: Current V1, destination V3, $d(V_1, V_3)=R\sqrt{3}$. Valid next V from V1 s.t. $d(V, V_3) < R\sqrt{3}$: V2 ($d(V_2, V_3)=R$), V3 ($d(V_3, V_3)=0$), V4 ($d(V_4, V_3)=R$). $N(V_1, V_3) = N(V_2, V_3) + N(V_3, V_3) + N(V_4, V_3)$. Since $N(V_2, V_3)=1$, $N(V_3, V_3)=1$, $N(V_4, V_3)=1$, we get $N(V_1, V_3) = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3$.
    To find $N(V_5, V_3)$: Current V5, destination V3, $d(V_5, V_3)=R\sqrt{3}$. By symmetry with V1, $N(V_5, V_3) = N(V_2, V_3) + N(V_3, V_3) + N(V_4, V_3) = 1 + 1 + 1 = 3$.
    Number of paths for Son 3 = $N(V_1, V_3) + N(V_2, V_3) + N(V_3, V_3) + N(V_4, V_3) + N(V_5, V_3) = 3 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 3 = 9$.

**3. Calculating Wedding Dates**

*   Each son starts on April 1st.
*   He makes one trip per day along a unique valid route until all routes are traveled.
*   The wedding is on the day following the last trip.
*   Son 1 has 1 path. He takes 1 trip on April 1st. His last trip is on April 1st (Day 1). Wedding on Day 1+1 = Day 2. **April 2nd**.
*   Son 2 has 3 paths. He takes trips on April 1st, April 2nd, April 3rd. His last trip is on April 3rd (Day 3). Wedding on Day 3+1 = Day 4. **April 4th**.
*   Son 3 has 9 paths. He takes trips on April 1st through April 9th. His last trip is on April 9th (Day 9). Wedding on Day 9+1 = Day 10. **April 10th**.

**4. Bonus Question: Longest Route Length**

The coastline is 10 miles long, so the circumference $2\pi R = 10$ miles, which means $R = 10/(2\pi)$ miles.

Let's list the lengths of the paths found for each son:
*   **Son 1 (V0 to V1):**
    *   V0 $\to$ V1: Length = $d(V_0, V_1) = R$. Max length for Son 1 is $R$.

*   **Son 2 (V0 to V2):**
    *   V0 $\to$ V2: Length = $d(V_0, V_2) = R\sqrt{3}$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V1 $\to$ V2: Length = $d(V_0, V_1) + d(V_1, V_2) = R + R = 2R$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V3 $\to$ V2: Length = $d(V_0, V_3) + d(V_3, V_2) = R\sqrt{3} + R = R(1+\sqrt{3})$.
    Comparing $R\sqrt{3} \approx 1.732R$, $2R$, and $R(1+\sqrt{3}) \approx 2.732R$, the maximum length for Son 2 is $R(1+\sqrt{3})$.

*   **Son 3 (V0 to V3):**
    *   V0 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_3) = 2R$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V1 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_1) + d(V_1, V3) = R + R\sqrt{3} = R(1+\sqrt{3})$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V1 $\to$ V2 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_1) + d(V_1, V_2) + d(V_2, V_3) = R + R + R = 3R$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V1 $\to$ V4 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_1) + d(V_1, V_4) + d(V_4, V_3) = R + 2R + R = 4R$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V2 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_2) + d(V_2, V_3) = R\sqrt{3} + R = R(1+\sqrt{3})$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V4 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_4) + d(V_4, V_3) = R\sqrt{3} + R = R(1+\sqrt{3})$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V5 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_5) + d(V_5, V_3) = R + R\sqrt{3} = R(1+\sqrt{3})$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V5 $\to$ V2 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_5) + d(V_5, V_2) + d(V_2, V_3) = R + 2R + R = 4R$.
    *   V0 $\to$ V5 $\to$ V4 $\to$ V3: Length = $d(V_0, V_5) + d(V_5, V_4) + d(V_4, V_3) = R + R + R = 3R$.
    The path lengths for Son 3 are $\{2R, R(1+\sqrt{3}), 3R, 4R\}$. The maximum length for Son 3 is $4R$.

The longest route any of the sons takes is the maximum of the longest routes for each son: Max($R$, $R(1+\sqrt{3})$, $4R$).
Comparing the coefficients 1, $1+\sqrt{3} \approx 2.732$, and 4, the largest is 4.
The longest route is $4R$.
Since $R = 10/(2\pi)$ miles, the longest route is $4 \times \frac{10}{2\pi} = \frac{40}{2\pi} = \frac{20}{\pi}$ miles.

The three wedding dates are April 2nd, April 4th, and April 10th.
The longest route length is $20/\pi$ miles.

Final answer: The three wedding dates are April 2nd, April 4th, and April 10th. The longest route is $20/\pi$ miles long.
Final Answer: The three wedding dates are April 2nd, April 4th, and April 10th. The longest route that any of the sons takes is $20/\pi$ miles.

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Here is the step-by-step solution:

1.  **Model the Island and Villages:**
    *   The island is perfectly round, and the six villages are evenly distributed along the coast. This means the villages form the vertices of a regular hexagon inscribed in the circle of the coastline.
    *   Let the villages be numbered V0, V1, V2, V3, V4, V5 in clockwise order.
    *   Let the father's village (where the sons start) be V0.
    *   The brides' villages are the first three encountered clockwise: V1, V2, and V3.
    *   Son 1 travels from V0 to V1.
    *   Son 2 travels from V0 to V2.
    *   Son 3 travels from V0 to V3.

2.  **Understand the Paths and the "Always Getting Closer" Rule:**
    *   There is a straight path connecting every pair of villages (these are the chords of the circle connecting the hexagon vertices).
    *   A route consists of traveling along one or more of these straight paths, potentially visiting intermediate villages.
    *   The crucial rule is that the traveler must *always* be getting closer to the destination village. This means that for any segment of the path, say from point A to point B, the straight-line Euclidean distance from B to the destination (D) must be strictly less than the straight-line distance from A to the destination (D). That is, distance(B, D) < distance(A, D).
    *   The points A and B in this rule are the villages visited along the route.

3.  **Calculate Distances Between Villages:**
    *   Let R be the radius of the circle circumscribing the hexagon. The vertices of the hexagon are the villages.
    *   The straight-line distance between two villages depends on how many villages apart they are along the coast.
    *   Distance between adjacent villages (e.g., V0 and V1): d1 = 2 * R * sin(pi/6) = 2 * R * (1/2) = R.
    *   Distance between villages separated by one village (e.g., V0 and V2): d2 = 2 * R * sin(2*pi/6) = 2 * R * sin(pi/3) = 2 * R * (sqrt(3)/2) = R * sqrt(3).
    *   Distance between opposite villages (e.g., V0 and V3): d3 = 2 * R * sin(3*pi/6) = 2 * R * sin(pi/2) = 2 * R * 1 = 2R.
    *   By symmetry: d(Vi, V(i+1)) = R; d(Vi, V(i+2)) = R*sqrt(3); d(Vi, V(i+3)) = 2R. (Indices are modulo 6).

4.  **Determine the Valid Routes for Each Son:**

    *   **Son 1: V0 to V1**
        *   Destination D = V1. Starting point A = V0. Initial distance = d(V0, V1) = R.
        *   Possible next villages B from V0: V1, V2, V3, V4, V5.
        *   Check if distance(B, V1) < distance(V0, V1) = R:
            *   B=V1: distance(V1, V1) = 0. Is 0 < R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V1**.
            *   B=V2: distance(V2, V1) = R. Is R < R? No. Invalid step.
            *   B=V3: distance(V3, V1) = d(V1, V3) = R*sqrt(3). Is R*sqrt(3) < R? No. Invalid step.
            *   B=V4: distance(V4, V1) = d(V1, V4) = 2R. Is 2R < R? No. Invalid step.
            *   B=V5: distance(V5, V1) = d(V1, V5) = R*sqrt(3). Is R*sqrt(3) < R? No. Invalid step.
        *   The only valid first step is directly to V1. No intermediate villages are possible because moving to any other village does not decrease the distance to V1.
        *   Number of valid routes for Son 1 = 1.

    *   **Son 2: V0 to V2**
        *   Destination D = V2. Starting point A = V0. Initial distance = d(V0, V2) = R*sqrt(3).
        *   Possible first steps B from V0: Check if distance(B, V2) < R*sqrt(3).
            *   B=V1: distance(V1, V2) = R. Is R < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Valid first step.
            *   B=V2: distance(V2, V2) = 0. Is 0 < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V2**.
            *   B=V3: distance(V3, V2) = R. Is R < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Valid first step.
            *   B=V4: distance(V4, V2) = R*sqrt(3). Is R*sqrt(3) < R*sqrt(3)? No. Invalid step.
            *   B=V5: distance(V5, V2) = 2R. Is 2R < R*sqrt(3)? No (2 > sqrt(3)). Invalid step.
        *   Valid first steps are V1, V2, V3.
        *   Explore paths starting V0 -> V1: Current location A=V1. Distance to D=V2 is d(V1, V2) = R.
            *   Possible next steps C from V1: Check if distance(C, V2) < R.
                *   C=V2: distance(V2, V2) = 0. Is 0 < R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V1 -> V2**.
                *   C=V3: distance(V3, V2) = R. Is R < R? No. Invalid step.
                *   Other villages (V0, V4, V5) are farther from V2 than R.
        *   Explore paths starting V0 -> V3: Current location A=V3. Distance to D=V2 is d(V3, V2) = R.
            *   Possible next steps C from V3: Check if distance(C, V2) < R.
                *   C=V2: distance(V2, V2) = 0. Is 0 < R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V3 -> V2**.
                *   C=V4: distance(V4, V2) = R*sqrt(3). Is R*sqrt(3) < R? No. Invalid step.
                *   Other villages (V0, V1, V5) are farther from V2 than R or distance R.
        *   The valid routes are: V0->V2, V0->V1->V2, V0->V3->V2.
        *   Number of valid routes for Son 2 = 3.

    *   **Son 3: V0 to V3**
        *   Destination D = V3. Starting point A = V0. Initial distance = d(V0, V3) = 2R.
        *   Distances of villages from V3: d(V0,V3)=2R, d(V1,V3)=R*sqrt(3), d(V2,V3)=R, d(V3,V3)=0, d(V4,V3)=R, d(V5,V3)=R*sqrt(3).
        *   Possible first steps B from V0: Check if distance(B, V3) < 2R.
            *   B=V1: distance(V1, V3) = R*sqrt(3). Is R*sqrt(3) < 2R? Yes. Valid.
            *   B=V2: distance(V2, V3) = R. Is R < 2R? Yes. Valid.
            *   B=V3: distance(V3, V3) = 0. Is 0 < 2R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V3**.
            *   B=V4: distance(V4, V3) = R. Is R < 2R? Yes. Valid.
            *   B=V5: distance(V5, V3) = R*sqrt(3). Is R*sqrt(3) < 2R? Yes. Valid.
        *   Valid first steps are V1, V2, V3, V4, V5.
        *   Explore paths starting V0 -> V1: Current A=V1. distance(A, D) = d(V1, V3) = R*sqrt(3).
            *   Next steps C from V1: Check if distance(C, V3) < R*sqrt(3).
                *   C=V2: distance(V2, V3) = R. Is R < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Path V0->V1->V2...
                *   C=V3: distance(V3, V3) = 0. Is 0 < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V1 -> V3**.
                *   C=V4: distance(V4, V3) = R. Is R < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Path V0->V1->V4...
                *   Other villages (V0, V5) do not decrease distance to V3.
            *   Explore V0 -> V1 -> V2: Current A=V2. distance(A, D) = d(V2, V3) = R.
                *   Next steps E from V2: Check if distance(E, V3) < R.
                    *   E=V3: distance(V3, V3) = 0. Is 0 < R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> V3**.
                    *   No other village is closer to V3 than R.
            *   Explore V0 -> V1 -> V4: Current A=V4. distance(A, D) = d(V4, V3) = R.
                *   Next steps E from V4: Check if distance(E, V3) < R.
                    *   E=V3: distance(V3, V3) = 0. Is 0 < R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3**.
                    *   No other village is closer to V3 than R.
        *   Explore paths starting V0 -> V2: Current A=V2. distance(A, D) = d(V2, V3) = R.
            *   Next steps C from V2: Check if distance(C, V3) < R.
                *   C=V3: distance(V3, V3) = 0. Is 0 < R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V2 -> V3**.
                *   No other village is closer.
        *   Explore paths starting V0 -> V4: Current A=V4. distance(A, D) = d(V4, V3) = R. (Symmetric to V0->V2)
            *   Next steps C from V4: Check if distance(C, V3) < R.
                *   C=V3: distance(V3, V3) = 0. Is 0 < R? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V4 -> V3**.
        *   Explore paths starting V0 -> V5: Current A=V5. distance(A, D) = d(V5, V3) = R*sqrt(3). (Symmetric to V0->V1)
            *   Next steps C from V5: Check if distance(C, V3) < R*sqrt(3).
                *   C=V4: distance(V4, V3) = R. Is R < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Path V0->V5->V4...
                *   C=V3: distance(V3, V3) = 0. Is 0 < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Path found: **V0 -> V5 -> V3**.
                *   C=V2: distance(V2, V3) = R. Is R < R*sqrt(3)? Yes. Path V0->V5->V2...
            *   Explore V0 -> V5 -> V4: Current A=V4. distance(A, D) = d(V4, V3) = R.
                *   Next step E=V3 only. Path found: **V0 -> V5 -> V4 -> V3**.
            *   Explore V0 -> V5 -> V2: Current A=V2. distance(A, D) = d(V2, V3) = R.
                *   Next step E=V3 only. Path found: **V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> V3**.

        *   List all valid routes for Son 3:
            1.  V0 -> V3
            2.  V0 -> V1 -> V3
            3.  V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> V3
            4.  V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3
            5.  V0 -> V2 -> V3
            6.  V0 -> V4 -> V3
            7.  V0 -> V5 -> V3
            8.  V0 -> V5 -> V4 -> V3
            9.  V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> V3
        *   Number of valid routes for Son 3 = 9.

5.  **Calculate the Wedding Dates:**
    *   The sons start on April 1st. Each takes one route per day. The wedding is the day after the last trip.
    *   Son 1: 1 route = 1 day. Last trip on April 1st. Wedding on **April 2nd**.
    *   Son 2: 3 routes = 3 days. Last trip on April 3rd. Wedding on **April 4th**.
    *   Son 3: 9 routes = 9 days. Last trip on April 9th. Wedding on **April 10th**.

6.  **Bonus Question: Longest Route Length:**
    *   The coastline is 10 miles long. This refers to the perimeter of the island along the coast, which is the circumference of the circle.
    *   Circumference C = 10 miles.
    *   C = 2 * pi * R_actual, where R_actual is the actual radius of the island.
    *   R_actual = 10 / (2 * pi) = 5/pi miles.
    *   The distances between villages are calculated using this actual radius R_actual = 5/pi. Let's call R_actual just R for simplicity in the distance formulas derived earlier: R = 5/pi miles.
        *   d1 = R = 5/pi miles (distance between adjacent villages).
        *   d2 = R*sqrt(3) = 5*sqrt(3)/pi miles (distance between villages separated by one).
        *   d3 = 2R = 10/pi miles (distance between opposite villages).
    *   Calculate the length of each type of valid route found:
        *   Son 1: V0->V1. Length = d1 = 5/pi.
        *   Son 2:
            *   V0->V2. Length = d2 = 5*sqrt(3)/pi.
            *   V0->V1->V2. Length = d1 + d1 = 2*d1 = 10/pi.
            *   V0->V3->V2. Length = d3 + d1 = 2R + R = 3R = 15/pi.
        *   Son 3:
            *   V0 -> V3. Length = d3 = 2R = 10/pi.
            *   V0 -> V1 -> V3. Length = d1 + d2 = R + R*sqrt(3) = R(1+sqrt(3)) = (5/pi)(1+sqrt(3)).
            *   V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> V3. Length = d1 + d1 + d1 = 3R = 15/pi.
            *   V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3. Length = d1 + d3 + d1 = R + 2R + R = 4R = 20/pi.
            *   V0 -> V2 -> V3. Length = d2 + d1 = R*sqrt(3) + R = R(1+sqrt(3)) = (5/pi)(1+sqrt(3)).
            *   V0 -> V4 -> V3. Length = d2 + d1 = R(1+sqrt(3)) = (5/pi)(1+sqrt(3)). (Symmetric to V0->V2->V3)
            *   V0 -> V5 -> V3. Length = d1 + d2 = R(1+sqrt(3)) = (5/pi)(1+sqrt(3)). (Symmetric to V0->V1->V3)
            *   V0 -> V5 -> V4 -> V3. Length = d1 + d1 + d1 = 3R = 15/pi. (Symmetric to V0->V1->V2->V3)
            *   V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> V3. Length = d1 + d3 + d1 = R + 2R + R = 4R = 20/pi. (Symmetric to V0->V1->V4->V3)
    *   The lengths encountered are: 5/pi, 5*sqrt(3)/pi, 10/pi, 15/pi, (5/pi)(1+sqrt(3)), 20/pi.
    *   Comparing these values (since pi is positive):
        *   5/pi ≈ 1.59
        *   5*sqrt(3)/pi ≈ 2.76
        *   10/pi ≈ 3.18
        *   15/pi ≈ 4.77
        *   (5/pi)(1+sqrt(3)) ≈ (5/pi)*2.732 ≈ 4.35
        *   20/pi ≈ 6.37
    *   The maximum length occurs for the routes V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3 and V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> V3.
    *   The longest route length is 4R = 4 * (5/pi) = 20/pi miles.

Final Summary:
Son 1 (V0->V1): 1 route. Wedding April 2nd.
Son 2 (V0->V2): 3 routes. Wedding April 4th.
Son 3 (V0->V3): 9 routes. Wedding April 10th.
Longest route length: 20/pi miles.

The logic for identifying paths seems sound based on the "always getting closer" rule and Euclidean distance between villages. The number of paths for each son (1, 3, 9) seems consistent. Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Final answer: The three wedding dates are April 2, April 4, and April 8. Bonus: The longest route is 5 miles. 

Final answer: April 2, April 4, April 8; Bonus: 5 miles. 

Final answer: April 2, April 4, April 8. Bonus: 5 miles. 

Final answer: The wedding dates are April 2, April 4, and April 8. Bonus: The longest route is 5 miles. 

Final answer: April 2, April 4, April 8. Bonus: 5 miles.

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
