Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Label the six coastal villages A,B,C,D,E,F in clockwise order round the island.
(The particular village we call A is immaterial – the picture is
a regular hexagon, so every statement that follows is independent of
where we start our lettering.)

For every two villages there is one straight path (a chord of the
circum‑circle); thus the paths form the complete graph K₆.
For any fixed destination village the young man is allowed to traverse
a chord only in the direction in which his distance from that
destination is strictly decreasing at every instant.

1.  Distances from one village to another  
   • between neighbours (e.g. A‑B) …………………… R  
   • with one village between (e.g. A‑C) ……… √3 R  
   • diametrically opposite (e.g. A‑D) …………… 2 R  
   (R is the radius of the island.)

2.  What does “always getting closer’’ allow?  
    If two villages are the same distance from the destination you
    may not go from one to the other, for at the beginning of that chord
    your distance is not decreasing.  Hence, travelling from a starting
    village S to a fixed destination D one may visit

        at most one village at distance 2 R from D,
        at most one at distance √3 R from D,
        at most one at distance R from D,

    and the distances must appear in strictly descending order.

3.  Counting the admissible routes

   a)  Destination and start are neighbours (distance R).  
       There is no intermediate village that is closer than R, so the
       only admissible route is the direct chord.  
       Number of routes = 1.

   b)  Destination and start are two apart (distance √3 R).  
       Possible stages:

            √3 R  →  (optionally one R–village)  →  0

       Choose a particular R–village or omit that step:
       2 + 1 = 3 routes altogether.

   c)  Destination and start are opposite (distance 2 R).  
       Possible stages:

            2 R  →  (0 or 1 of the two √3 R villages)
                   →  (0 or 1 of the two R villages)  →  0.

       Selecting one √3 R village (2 ways) and one R village (2 ways)
       gives 4 routes, selecting only a √3 R village gives 2,
       selecting only an R village gives 2, selecting none gives 1.  
       Total routes = 4 + 2 + 2 + 1 = 9.

   So:

        adjacent villages ………………… 1 route
        one apart (two steps) ………… 3 routes
        opposite …………………………… 9 routes

4.  Which couples are involved?  
    The three brides live in the first three villages encountered while
    going clockwise from the suitors’ home village A, i.e. in B, C, D.
    Therefore the three pairs (suitor’s village, bride’s village) are

        A → B  (adjacent)     … 1 route
        A → C  (two apart)    … 3 routes
        A → D  (opposite)     … 9 routes

5.  Wedding dates  
    Every suitor brings a fish along one new route each day, beginning
    on April 1; the marriage takes place the day after he has used the
    last available route.

        A → B : 1 day of carrying fish  → last trip 1 April,
                                          wedding 2 April.
        A → C : 3 days of carrying fish → last trip 3 April,
                                          wedding 4 April.
        A → D : 9 days of carrying fish → last trip 9 April,
                                          wedding 10 April.

   Hence the three weddings are on

        2 April, 4 April, 10 April.

6.  Bonus – the longest single route

    The longest admissible route occurs in the opposite‑village case
    A → D when the suitor inserts both an intervening √3 R village and
    an intervening R village, for instance

          D  ← B  ← C  ← A

    Every leg of that particular path is a side of the hexagon, length R,
    so the total length is 3 R.

    The island’s coastline is 10 mi, so

          2πR = 10  ⇒  R = 5/π miles.

    Longest route length = 3R = 15/π ≈ 4.77 miles.

Final answer:  The weddings occur on April 2, April 4, and April 10;  
the longest route any son travels is 15 ⁄ π ≈ 4.77 miles.

Response:
The six villages are evenly distributed along the coastline of a perfectly round island. Let the villages be $V_1, V_2, V_3, V_4, V_5, V_6$ in clockwise order. The straight paths between any two villages are chords of the island's circle. The villages form the vertices of a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle. Let $R$ be the length of the straight path between adjacent villages (the side length of the hexagon). This length is equal to the radius of the circumscribed circle.

The coastline of the island is 10 miles long. Since the villages are evenly distributed, the arc length between any two neighboring villages is $10/6 = 5/3$ miles. For a regular hexagon with side length $R$ inscribed in a circle of radius $r$, the angle subtended by a side at the center is $2\pi/6 = \pi/3$ radians. The arc length $s_{arc}$ is related to the radius $r$ by $s_{arc} = r \theta$. Thus, $5/3 = r(\pi/3)$, which gives the radius $r = 5/\pi$ miles. The straight-line distance between adjacent villages is $R=r=5/\pi$ miles.

The straight-line distance between any two villages $V_i$ and $V_j$ can be calculated using the law of cosines, or by noting that the distance is $2r \sin(k\pi/6)$ where $k=|i-j|$ (modulo 6, using the shortest distance around the hexagon). The possible distances are:
$d(V_i, V_{i+1}) = R = 5/\pi$ (side length)
$d(V_i, V_{i+2}) = R\sqrt{3} = (5/\pi)\sqrt{3}$ (short diagonal)
$d(V_i, V_{i+3}) = 2R = 10/\pi$ (main diagonal)

Let the father's village be $V_1$. The brides' villages are the first three encountered clockwise from $V_1$, which are $V_2, V_3, V_4$. The sons are the suitors, and they are from $V_1$. Each son travels from his village ($V_1$) to the bride's father's village ($V_2, V_3,$ or $V_4$).

A route is a sequence of villages $U_0, U_1, \dots, U_k$ where $U_0=V_S$, $U_k=V_D$, $U_i U_{i+1}$ is a straight path between villages, and the distance from $U_{i+1}$ to the destination $V_D$ is strictly less than the distance from $U_i$ to $V_D$. $d(U_{i+1}, V_D) < d(U_i, V_D)$.

Son 1: From $V_1$ to $V_2$. $V_D=V_2$.
Distances to $V_2$: $d(V_1, V_2)=R$, $d(V_3, V_2)=R$, $d(V_4, V_2)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_5, V_2)=2R$, $d(V_6, V_2)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_2, V_2)=0$.
From $V_1$: $d(V_1, V_2)=R$. A step $V_1 \to U$ is valid if $d(U, V_2)<R$. Only $U=V_2$ satisfies this ($d(V_2, V_2)=0$).
There is only 1 route for Son 1: $V_1 \to V_2$.

Son 2: From $V_1$ to $V_3$. $V_D=V_3$.
Distances to $V_3$: $d(V_1, V_3)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_2, V_3)=R$, $d(V_4, V_3)=R$, $d(V_5, V_3)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_6, V_3)=2R$, $d(V_3, V_3)=0$.
From $V_1$: $d(V_1, V_3)=R\sqrt{3}$. A step $V_1 \to U$ is valid if $d(U, V_3)<R\sqrt{3}$. $U \in \{V_2, V_3, V_4\}$.
- $V_1 \to V_3$: Direct route. Valid. (1 route)
- $V_1 \to V_2$: $d(V_2, V_3)=R$. From $V_2$, must go to $U'$ with $d(U', V_3)<R$. Only $U'=V_3$. Route $V_1 \to V_2 \to V_3$. Valid. (1 route)
- $V_1 \to V_4$: $d(V_4, V_3)=R$. From $V_4$, must go to $U'$ with $d(U', V_3)<R$. Only $U'=V_3$. Route $V_1 \to V_4 \to V_3$. Valid. (1 route)
There are 3 routes for Son 2: $V_1 \to V_3$, $V_1 \to V_2 \to V_3$, $V_1 \to V_4 \to V_3$.

Son 3: From $V_1$ to $V_4$. $V_D=V_4$.
Distances to $V_4$: $d(V_1, V_4)=2R$, $d(V_2, V_4)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_3, V_4)=R$, $d(V_5, V_4)=R$, $d(V_6, V_4)=R\sqrt{3}$, $d(V_4, V_4)=0$.
From $V_1$: $d(V_1, V_4)=2R$. A step $V_1 \to U$ is valid if $d(U, V_4)<2R$. $U \in \{V_2, V_3, V_4, V_5, V_6\}$.
Let $N(V_S, V_D)$ be the number of routes from $V_S$ to $V_D$.
$N(V_1, V_4)$:
- $V_1 \to V_4$ (1 route)
- $V_1 \to V_2$: $d(V_2, V_4)=R\sqrt{3}$. From $V_2$, $d(U, V_4)<R\sqrt{3}$. $U \in \{V_3, V_4, V_5\}$.
  - $V_2 \to V_3$: $d(V_3, V_4)=R$. From $V_3$, $d(U', V_4)<R$. Only $U'=V_4$. $V_1 \to V_2 \to V_3 \to V_4$.
  - $V_2 \to V_4$: $V_1 \to V_2 \to V_4$.
  - $V_2 \to V_5$: $d(V_5, V_4)=R$. From $V_5$, $d(U', V_4)<R$. Only $U'=V_4$. $V_1 \to V_2 \to V_5 \to V_4$. (3 routes starting with $V_1 \to V_2$)
- $V_1 \to V_3$: $d(V_3, V_4)=R$. From $V_3$, $d(U, V_4)<R$. Only $U=V_4$. $V_1 \to V_3 \to V_4$. (1 route starting with $V_1 \to V_3$)
- $V_1 \to V_5$: $d(V_5, V_4)=R$. From $V_5$, $d(U, V_4)<R$. Only $U=V_4$. $V_1 \to V_5 \to V_4$. (1 route starting with $V_1 \to V_5$)
- $V_1 \to V_6$: $d(V_6, V_4)=R\sqrt{3}$. From $V_6$, $d(U, V_4)<R\sqrt{3}$. $U \in \{V_3, V_4, V_5\}$.
  - $V_6 \to V_3$: $d(V_3, V_4)=R$. From $V_3$, $d(U', V_4)<R$. Only $U'=V_4$. $V_1 \to V_6 \to V_3 \to V_4$.
  - $V_6 \to V_4$: $V_1 \to V_6 \to V_4$.
  - $V_6 \to V_5$: $d(V_5, V_4)=R$. From $V_5$, $d(U', V_4)<R$. Only $U'=V_4$. $V_1 \to V_6 \to V_5 \to V_4$. (3 routes starting with $V_1 \to V_6$)

Total routes for Son 3: $1 + 3 + 1 + 1 + 3 = 9$ routes.

The number of routes for the three sons are 1, 3, and 9.
The sons begin courtship on April first. Each day a son travels one route.
Son courting bride in $V_2$: 1 route. Finishes on Day 1 (April 1). Wedding on Day 2 (April 2).
Son courting bride in $V_3$: 3 routes. Finishes on Day 3 (April 3). Wedding on Day 4 (April 4).
Son courting bride in $V_4$: 9 routes. Finishes on Day 9 (April 9). Wedding on Day 10 (April 10).
The three wedding dates are April 2nd, April 4th, and April 10th.

Bonus Question: Longest route length.
The path lengths are the sum of the lengths of the segments $U_i U_{i+1}$.
Son 1: $V_1 \to V_2$. Length $d(V_1, V_2) = R = 5/\pi$.
Son 2:
$V_1 \to V_3$. Length $d(V_1, V_3) = R\sqrt{3} = (5/\pi)\sqrt{3}$.
$V_1 \to V_2 \to V_3$. Length $d(V_1, V_2) + d(V_2, V_3) = R + R = 2R = 10/\pi$.
$V_1 \to V_4 \to V_3$. Length $d(V_1, V_4) + d(V_4, V_3) = 2R + R = 3R = 15/\pi$.
Lengths for Son 2: $R\sqrt{3} \approx 2.75$, $2R \approx 3.18$, $3R \approx 4.77$. Longest is $3R$.
Son 3:
$V_1 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_4) = 2R = 10/\pi$.
$V_1 \to V_3 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_3) + d(V_3, V_4) = R\sqrt{3} + R = (5/\pi)(\sqrt{3}+1) \approx 4.90$.
$V_1 \to V_5 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_5) + d(V_5, V_4) = R\sqrt{3} + R = (5/\pi)(\sqrt{3}+1) \approx 4.90$.
$V_1 \to V_2 \to V_3 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_2)+d(V_2, V_3)+d(V_3, V_4) = R+R+R = 3R = 15/\pi$.
$V_1 \to V_2 \to V_5 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_2)+d(V_2, V_5)+d(V_5, V_4) = R+2R+R = 4R = 20/\pi$.
$V_1 \to V_6 \to V_3 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_6)+d(V_6, V_3)+d(V_3, V_4) = R+2R+R = 4R = 20/\pi$.
$V_1 \to V_6 \to V_5 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_6)+d(V_6, V_5)+d(V_5, V_4) = R+R+R = 3R = 15/\pi$.
$V_1 \to V_2 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_2) + d(V_2, V_4) = R + R\sqrt{3} = (5/\pi)(1+\sqrt{3}) \approx 4.90$.
$V_1 \to V_6 \to V_4$. Length $d(V_1, V_6) + d(V_6, V_4) = R + R\sqrt{3} = (5/\pi)(1+\sqrt{3}) \approx 4.90$.
Lengths for Son 3: $2R=10/\pi \approx 3.18$, $R\sqrt{3}+R \approx 4.90$, $3R \approx 4.77$, $4R \approx 6.37$. Longest is $4R$.

Comparing the longest routes for each son:
Son 1: $R = 5/\pi \approx 1.59$ miles.
Son 2: $3R = 15/\pi \approx 4.77$ miles.
Son 3: $4R = 20/\pi \approx 6.37$ miles.
The longest route any of the sons takes is $4R = 20/\pi$ miles.

The three wedding dates are April 2nd, April 4th, and April 10th.
The longest route length is $20/\pi$ miles.

Final Answer format requested. Wedding dates first, then Bonus Question.

The three wedding dates are April 2, April 4, and April 10.
Bonus Question: The longest route any of the sons takes is $20/\pi$ miles.

The final answer is $\boxed{April\ 2, April\ 4, April\ 10}$.

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
**1. Understand the Setup**

*   There are 6 villages (V0, V1, V2, V3, V4, V5) evenly spaced on a circular island coastline. Let the father's village be V0.
*   The three sons start from V0.
*   The brides are in villages V1, V2, and V3 (the first three clockwise from V0).
    *   Son 1 goes V0 -> V1.
    *   Son 2 goes V0 -> V2.
    *   Son 3 goes V0 -> V3.
*   Straight paths connect every pair of villages.
*   A valid courtship route is a sequence of villages starting at the son's village (V0) and ending at the bride's village (Vd), possibly visiting other villages (Vi) along the way.
*   The condition for a valid route is that at each step (moving from village Va to village Vb), the straight-line distance to the destination village Vd must strictly decrease: D(Vb, Vd) < D(Va, Vd).
*   The number of days required for courtship equals the number of distinct valid routes. Courtship starts April 1st. The wedding is the day after the last trip.

**2. Calculate Distances Between Villages**

*   Let the radius of the island be R. The villages form a regular hexagon. The straight-line distance between Vi and Vj is given by D(Vi, Vj) = 2*R * |sin((i - j)*pi/6)|.
*   D(Adjacent, e.g., V0, V1) = 2R*sin(pi/6) = R.
*   D(Skip 1, e.g., V0, V2) = 2R*sin(2*pi/6) = 2R*sin(pi/3) = R*sqrt(3).
*   D(Opposite, e.g., V0, V3) = 2R*sin(3*pi/6) = 2R*sin(pi/2) = 2R.
*   By symmetry, D(Vi, Vj) depends only on the separation |i - j| (modulo 6).
    *   Separation 1 (or 5): Distance R
    *   Separation 2 (or 4): Distance R*sqrt(3)
    *   Separation 3: Distance 2R

**3. Determine Valid Routes for Son 1 (V0 -> V1)**

*   Destination V1. Start V0. Initial distance D(V0, V1) = R.
*   A path V0 -> Vk -> ... is valid only if D(Vk, V1) < D(V0, V1) = R.
*   Let's check possible intermediate villages Vk (V2, V3, V4, V5):
    *   D(V2, V1) = R. Not strictly less than R.
    *   D(V3, V1) = R*sqrt(3). Not less than R.
    *   D(V4, V1) = 2R. Not less than R.
    *   D(V5, V1) = R*sqrt(3). Not less than R.
*   No intermediate village can be visited first. The only step possible from V0 is directly to V1, because D(V1, V1) = 0 < D(V0, V1) = R.
*   Therefore, the only valid route is V0 -> V1.
*   Number of routes for Son 1 = 1.

**4. Determine Valid Routes for Son 2 (V0 -> V2)**

*   Destination V2. Start V0. Initial distance D(V0, V2) = R*sqrt(3).
*   A path V0 -> Vk -> ... is valid only if D(Vk, V2) < D(V0, V2) = R*sqrt(3).
*   Check possible first intermediate villages Vk (V1, V3, V4, V5):
    *   D(V1, V2) = R. R < R*sqrt(3). Valid first step: V0 -> V1.
    *   D(V3, V2) = R. R < R*sqrt(3). Valid first step: V0 -> V3.
    *   D(V4, V2) = R*sqrt(3). Not strictly less than R*sqrt(3). Invalid first step.
    *   D(V5, V2) = 2R. Not less than R*sqrt(3). Invalid first step.
*   The direct route V0 -> V2 is also valid because D(V2, V2) = 0 < D(V0, V2).
*   Consider routes starting V0 -> V1:
    *   Current village V1. Distance to V2 is D(V1, V2) = R.
    *   Need next village Vx such that D(Vx, V2) < D(V1, V2) = R.
    *   Possible next villages (not V0): V3, V4, V5.
    *   D(V3, V2) = R. Not strictly less.
    *   D(V4, V2) = R*sqrt(3). Not less.
    *   D(V5, V2) = 2R. Not less.
    *   The only valid next step is directly to V2, since D(V2, V2) = 0 < R.
    *   Route: V0 -> V1 -> V2. Valid.
*   Consider routes starting V0 -> V3:
    *   Current village V3. Distance to V2 is D(V3, V2) = R.
    *   Need next village Vx such that D(Vx, V2) < D(V3, V2) = R.
    *   Possible next villages (not V0): V1, V4, V5.
    *   D(V1, V2) = R. Not strictly less.
    *   D(V4, V2) = R*sqrt(3). Not less.
    *   D(V5, V2) = 2R. Not less.
    *   The only valid next step is directly to V2, since D(V2, V2) = 0 < R.
    *   Route: V0 -> V3 -> V2. Valid.
*   Valid routes: V0 -> V2, V0 -> V1 -> V2, V0 -> V3 -> V2.
*   Number of routes for Son 2 = 3.

**5. Determine Valid Routes for Son 3 (V0 -> V3)**

*   Destination V3. Start V0. Initial distance D(V0, V3) = 2R.
*   A path V0 -> Vk -> ... is valid only if D(Vk, V3) < D(V0, V3) = 2R.
*   Check possible first intermediate villages Vk (V1, V2, V4, V5):
    *   D(V1, V3) = R*sqrt(3). R*sqrt(3) < 2R. Valid first step: V0 -> V1.
    *   D(V2, V3) = R. R < 2R. Valid first step: V0 -> V2.
    *   D(V4, V3) = R. R < 2R. Valid first step: V0 -> V4.
    *   D(V5, V3) = R*sqrt(3). R*sqrt(3) < 2R. Valid first step: V0 -> V5.
*   The direct route V0 -> V3 is also valid because D(V3, V3) = 0 < D(V0, V3).
*   We can systematically find all paths using the distance condition:
    *   Route 1: V0 -> V3 (Direct)
    *   Routes starting V0 -> V1: (Current V1, Dist to V3 = R*sqrt(3))
        *   Need next Vx where D(Vx, V3) < R*sqrt(3). Possible: V2 (Dist R), V4 (Dist R), V3 (Dist 0).
        *   V0 -> V1 -> V3 (Valid: D(V3,V3)=0 < D(V1,V3)=R*sqrt(3))
        *   V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> ... (Current V2, Dist to V3 = R). Need Vy where D(Vy, V3) < R. Possible: V3 (Dist 0).
            *   Route 2: V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> V3 (Valid)
        *   V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> ... (Current V4, Dist to V3 = R). Need Vy where D(Vy, V3) < R. Possible: V3 (Dist 0).
            *   Route 3: V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3 (Valid)
    *   Routes starting V0 -> V2: (Current V2, Dist to V3 = R)
        *   Need next Vx where D(Vx, V3) < R. Possible: V3 (Dist 0).
        *   Route 4: V0 -> V2 -> V3 (Valid)
    *   Routes starting V0 -> V4: (Current V4, Dist to V3 = R)
        *   Need next Vx where D(Vx, V3) < R. Possible: V3 (Dist 0).
        *   Route 5: V0 -> V4 -> V3 (Valid)
    *   Routes starting V0 -> V5: (Current V5, Dist to V3 = R*sqrt(3))
        *   Need next Vx where D(Vx, V3) < R*sqrt(3). Possible: V2 (Dist R), V4 (Dist R), V3 (Dist 0).
        *   V0 -> V5 -> V3 (Valid: D(V3,V3)=0 < D(V5,V3)=R*sqrt(3))
        *   V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> ... (Current V2, Dist to V3 = R). Need Vy where D(Vy, V3) < R. Possible: V3 (Dist 0).
            *   Route 6: V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> V3 (Valid)
        *   V0 -> V5 -> V4 -> ... (Current V4, Dist to V3 = R). Need Vy where D(Vy, V3) < R. Possible: V3 (Dist 0).
            *   Route 7: V0 -> V5 -> V4 -> V3 (Valid)
*   Let's list them cleanly:
    1.  V0 -> V3
    2.  V0 -> V1 -> V3
    3.  V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> V3
    4.  V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3
    5.  V0 -> V2 -> V3
    6.  V0 -> V4 -> V3
    7.  V0 -> V5 -> V3
    8.  V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> V3
    9.  V0 -> V5 -> V4 -> V3
*   Number of routes for Son 3 = 9.

**6. Calculate Wedding Dates**

*   Start date: April 1st.
*   Son 1 (V0 -> V1): 1 route = 1 day. Finishes April 1st. Wedding: April 2nd.
*   Son 2 (V0 -> V2): 3 routes = 3 days. Finishes April 3rd. Wedding: April 4th.
*   Son 3 (V0 -> V3): 9 routes = 9 days. Finishes April 9th. Wedding: April 10th.

**7. Bonus Question: Longest Route Length**

*   Coastline length = 10 miles. This is the circumference, 2 * pi * R = 10.
*   So, R = 10 / (2 * pi) = 5 / pi miles.
*   We need to calculate the length of all valid routes found and find the maximum. The length of a route is the sum of the straight-line distances between consecutive villages in the route.
*   Route Length = Sum of segment lengths D(Va, Vb).
    *   Segments have length R, R*sqrt(3), or 2R.
*   Son 1: V0 -> V1. Length = D(V0, V1) = R = 5/pi.
*   Son 2:
    *   V0 -> V2: Length = D(V0, V2) = R*sqrt(3) = 5*sqrt(3)/pi.
    *   V0 -> V1 -> V2: Length = D(V0, V1) + D(V1, V2) = R + R = 2R = 10/pi.
    *   V0 -> V3 -> V2: Length = D(V0, V3) + D(V3, V2) = 2R + R = 3R = 15/pi.
*   Son 3:
    *   V0 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V3) = 2R = 10/pi.
    *   V0 -> V1 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V1) + D(V1, V3) = R + R*sqrt(3) = (5/pi)*(1 + sqrt(3)).
    *   V0 -> V1 -> V2 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V1) + D(V1, V2) + D(V2, V3) = R + R + R = 3R = 15/pi.
    *   V0 -> V1 -> V4 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V1) + D(V1, V4) + D(V4, V3) = R + 2R + R = 4R = 20/pi. (V1 and V4 are opposite).
    *   V0 -> V2 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V2) + D(V2, V3) = R*sqrt(3) + R = (5/pi)*(1 + sqrt(3)).
    *   V0 -> V4 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V4) + D(V4, V3) = R*sqrt(3) + R = (5/pi)*(1 + sqrt(3)).
    *   V0 -> V5 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V5) + D(V5, V3) = R + R*sqrt(3) = (5/pi)*(1 + sqrt(3)).
    *   V0 -> V5 -> V2 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V5) + D(V5, V2) + D(V2, V3) = R + 2R + R = 4R = 20/pi. (V5 and V2 are opposite).
    *   V0 -> V5 -> V4 -> V3: Length = D(V0, V5) + D(V5, V4) + D(V4, V3) = R + R + R = 3R = 15/pi.
*   Comparing the lengths: R, R*sqrt(3), 2R, 3R, 4R, R*(1+sqrt(3)).
    *   R ≈ 1.59 * (5/pi)
    *   R*sqrt(3) ≈ 2.76 * (5/pi)
    *   2R ≈ 3.18 * (5/pi)
    *   R*(1+sqrt(3)) ≈ 4.34 * (5/pi)
    *   3R ≈ 4.77 * (5/pi)
    *   4R ≈ 6.37 * (5/pi)
*   The maximum length is 4R = 4 * (5/pi) = 20/pi miles.

**Final Answer Formulation**

*   The three wedding dates are April 2nd, April 4th, and April 10th.
*   The longest route length is 20/pi miles.

Final check of logic and calculations. All steps seem justified and calculations correct. The interpretation of the rules seems the most plausible one.

Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{April 2nd, April 4th, April 10th}$
Bonus Question: The final answer is $\boxed{20/\pi \text{ miles}}$

1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.

The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.

1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.

Response:
The problem involves six villages evenly spaced around a circular island. The key is determining the number of valid routes each son must travel from his village to his bride's village, always moving closer. 

1. **Village Arrangement**: Label the villages 0 to 5 clockwise. Assume the father is at village 0, and the brides are in villages 1, 2, and 3 (the first three clockwise). The sons start from three distinct villages (e.g., 3, 4, 5).

2. **Route Analysis**:
   - **Son courting village 1**: From village 3, the shortest path is 3 → 2 → 1 (2 steps). Only one valid route.
   - **Son courting village 2**: From village 4, the shortest path is 4 → 3 → 2 (2 steps). Only one valid route.
   - **Son courting village 3**: From village 5, the shortest path is 5 → 4 → 3 (2 steps). Only one valid route.

3. **Wedding Dates**: Each son completes their single route on April 1, leading to weddings the next day.

**Final answer**: April 2, April 2, April 2.  
**Bonus Answer**: The longest route is the diameter of the island. With a 10-mile coastline (circumference), the radius \( r = \frac{10}{2\pi} \). The diameter (longest straight-line distance) is \( 2r = \frac{10}{\pi} \approx 3.18 \) miles.  

**Final answer**: April 2, April 2, April 2.  
**Bonus Answer**: \(\boxed{\dfrac{10}{\pi}}\) miles.

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

Question:
There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

Question:
Question: There are six villages along the coast of the only perfectly round island in the known universe.  The villages are evenly distributed along the coastline so that the distance between any two neighboring coastal villages is always the same.  There is an absolutely straight path through the jungle connecting every pair of villages.  These paths create thirteen crossings in the interior of the island, one of which is in the middle of the island where paths from every village meet.
The island has a strange courtship custom.  Before a father will give permission for his daughter to marry, her suitor must bring the father a fish each day until he has traveled by every route from his village to the father's village.  The young man only travels along routes where he is always getting closer to his destination.  The young man may visit other villages along the way.
On April first a father's three sons come to tell him of their intent to woe a bride, each from a different village.  The brides' villages are the first three villages encountered when traveling clockwise around the island.
If the sons begin their courtship today and the couples are married on the day following each son's last trip, what are the three wedding dates?
Bonus Question:  If the coastline of the island is ten miles long, how long is the longest route that any of the sons takes to reach their betrothed's village?
 Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles
Response:
Numbering the six coastal villages clockwise V0 ,V1 ,V2 ,V3 ,V4 ,V5 we may, without loss of generality, let the three brides live in V0 ,V1 ,V2; the three suitors live in the remaining villages V3 ,V4 ,V5 (the statement only says that the brides’ villages are the first three met when one proceeds clockwise and that the sons come from the other three villages; the exact labelling is arbitrary).

For every pair of villages there is a straight path (chord of the circum‑circle).  
With all chords drawn the interior contains 13 crossings (19 nodes altogether: the 6 villages + the 13 crossings).  
For a fixed destination the rule “always getting closer’’ makes every segment of every chord a one‑way street that leads strictly toward that destination; the resulting directed graph is acyclic, so the number of admissible routes from any node to the destination is obtained by dynamic programming:

1.  give the destination the value 1;  
2.  scan the graph outward, assigning to each new node the sum of the values already written on all nodes that can be reached from it in one step.

Carrying this out for destination V0 gives (only the values needed later are shown):

• V0 : 1  
• its two neighbours V1 ,V5 and the centre C : 1  
• the two nearest crossings on V0V2 and V0V4 (call them A, B) : 2  
• the two crossings J, M lying one step farther out on V1V3 and V3V5 : 3 and 2 respectively  
• the crossing N on V0V3 – V2V4 : 1  
• the villages two steps away, V2 and V4 : 7  
• the opposite village V3 : 20

Because of 6‑fold rotational symmetry the same table (rotated) holds for every choice of destination.  Consequently

• a suitor who is adjacent to his bride (distance one side of the hexagon) has to use 1 route;  
• a suitor two steps away has to use 7 routes;  
• a suitor diametrically opposite has to use 20 routes.

The three sons fit these three situations, so they need 1, 7 and 20 days respectively.  
They start on April 1; the weddings take place on the day after each man has completed all of his routes.

1 day   → wedding on 2 April  
7 days  → wedding on 8 April  
20 days → wedding on 21 April

Bonus – longest single route  
The longest admissible route is

V3 → V2 (one side of the hexagon)  
V2 → V5 (the long diagonal through the centre)  
V5 → V0 (one side)

Its length is

side + long‑diagonal + side  
= r + 2r + r = 4r  with r = (circumference)/(2π) = 5/π miles

4r = 20/π ≃ 6.37 miles.

Final answer:  the weddings are on 2 April, 8 April and 21 April; the longest single trip any son makes is about 6.37 miles.
